title: Using a gap year to boost your career – live chat | Guardian Careers
text:
“Four years ago I packed a suitcase and boarded a flight to Australia. I had no job lined up. Nowhere to live. There was nothing to fall back on,” says Beverley Reinemann, a gap-year student who used her experience to build a career in online marketing.
“If you do it right, a gap year can give you the extra skills you need to outshine other candidates when you return home,” she adds.
Around 2.5 million students embark on a gap year each year, with most young Britons using this time to volunteer for charities overseas. To boost your CV, it can also be helpful to combine volunteering with internships and part-time roles.
“One of the gap year’s most undervalued advantages is the ability to undertake work placements outside of the over-subscribed holiday periods,” says gap-year student Katherine Hodgson. “My part-time job also funds the volunteering and keeps me, and my CV, busy.”
Taking a year out can also give you valuable time to consider different career paths. “It can give you a taste of different sectors and work environments, allowing you to find out what you like and don’t like in a workplace,” she adds.
So, if you’re looking to make the most of a year out from work or study, join us on Thursday 10 September from 1pm-3pm BST for a live chat with the experts. We’ll be discussing:
How to use a gap year to boost your CV. Ways to explore career options on your year out. Advice on applying for gap-year schemes.
The Q&A will take place in the comments section below this article. Taking part is easier than ever: create a free Guardian account , or log in using your Twitter or Facebook profiles to comment. Alternatively, you can tweet us @GuardianCareers or email your questions to charlotte.seager@theguardian.com , who can post them for you.
Comments are currently open and we welcome questions in advance.
Panel Richard Nimmo is chair of the Year Out Group , a trade association that promotes the benefits of well-structured gap year programmes. He is also managing director of Blue Ventures Expeditions , an ecotourism organisation that offers tourism expeditions for years abroad.
Joe Hallwood is the founder of Tefl Org UK , and has worked in TEFL for over 20 years advising graduates on teaching overseas. Prior to this, he taught English for eight years in Greece and France, before returning to the UK to retrain in marketing.
Arthur Ashman is talent development leader at Inspiring Interns – and works to help students find work placements on their year abroad. Ashman studied Medicine at UCL before pursuing a career in HR which involves advising and matching graduates to careers.
Sophie Graham is a careers adviser for the National Careers Service, specialising in matching young people and graduates to careers. Graham also works for the National Careers Service Helpline and regularly attends careers fairs, UCAS events, Skills Shows and Employment Roadshows.
Vicky McNeil-Kornevall is the co-founder of WorkingAbroad.com – one of the most popular websites on voluntary work overseas. She has supported projects across five continents and has successfully placed thousands of volunteers in humanitarian and environmental positions.
Craig Phillips is a careers consultant at the University of Edinburgh. He has over five years’ experience advising graduates on making the most of their degrees and experience, and co-edits the Careers Service labour market blog .
Dasha Amrom is a founder and managing director of Career Coaching Ventures – a career and business coaching consultancy. Career Coaching Ventures provides CV and cover letter advice and career coaching for those looking to work abroad.
Lisa LaRue is a qualified career coach with over 15 years experience. She runs CareerWorx , a career consultancy providing CV advice, interview coaching, outplacement support and job skills training.
